properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A line of thunderstorms located from Port Stanley to Cleveland will move across Lake Erie this evening. Some of these thunderstorms may be capable of producing wind gusts up to 35 knots. ### Large hail can damage vessels and cause injury. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2019-04-15T05:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T22:26:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1742401095.2019
Area: Eastern Lake Erie, Western Lake Erie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of snow, blowing snow, and strong winds is expected from Monday night through to Wednesday morning. Snow will develop Monday evening and may become heavy at times overnight Monday into Tuesday. Total snowfall accumulations could exceed 30 cm in some areas by Wednesday morning, particularly inland and over higher elevations. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to between 70 and 90 km/h will accompany the snow and cause poor visibilities in blowing snow, especially on Tuesday and Tuesday night. The snow is expected to taper off by Wednesday morning but strong northerly winds will continue through the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T19:52:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T01:33:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1010541785.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm are possible. The ground is still at least partially frozen over portions of Southern Ontario. As a result, the ground will have a limited ability to absorb this rainfall. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. The rain will likely change to snow Monday morning, but accumulations should be light. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T04:49:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T20:50:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3277760687.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 cm of snow possible for Kootenay Pass tonight. A cool unstable airmass will persist over the BC Interior tonight giving a few flurries over most of the mountain passes. Over Kootenay Pass a more organized band of precipitation will move through late this evening producing up to 5 cm of snow accumulation. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T12:21:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T04:22:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1924647386.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for early this week. A developing weather system is expected to bring an extended period of strong winds and a variety of precipitation types for the first half of this week. Precipitation will begin as rain or snow mixed with ice pellets on Monday. Freezing rain is possible for some areas Monday evening before the precipitation changes to rain later Monday night. There is potential for rainfall amounts to reach or exceed the 25 mm rainfall warning criteria before the rain tapers to showers and flurries on Tuesday. Strong easterly winds are also likely Monday night into Tuesday morning along the West Coast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T09:27:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T01:28:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2714457016.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall this evening. An area of heavy rain with embedded thunderstorms is moving through the Golden Horseshoe this evening. It should move east of the area by late evening. Only light precipitation is expected in the overnight period. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are likely, with the highest amounts most likely over Niagara and areas east of Toronto. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. Rain will end from west to east overnight or Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T08:27:24-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for early this week. A developing weather system is expected to bring an extended period of strong winds and a variety of precipitation types for the first half of this week. Precipitation will begin as showers or flurries Monday evening. Over the northern Avalon, precipitation will change to an extended period of freezing rain or ice pellets later Monday evening before changing to rain early Tuesday morning. Over areas of the Northeast Coast, the showers or flurries will change to snow or ice pellets late Monday evening, before changing to an extended period of freezing rain or ice pellets near midnight. The freezing rain is forecast to change to rain showers Tuesday morning. A freezing rain warning may be required for these areas with future forecasts. Colder air and northerly winds will follow Tuesday night into Wednesday, changing precipitation back to snow, with accumulation possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T09:31:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T01:32:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1015732616.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system approaching the province from the southwest is forecast to cross New Brunswick on Monday night before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Over southern New Brunswick, this system is expected to bring predominately rain, beginning tonight. A brief changeover to snow is likely Monday night as the low moves away. Precipitation will taper off over all areas through the day on Tuesday. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are forecast. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T08:57:48-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for early this week. A developing weather system is expected to bring an extended period of strong winds and a variety of precipitation types for the first half of this week. Precipitation will begin as rain Monday afternoon and change to a wintry mix of snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain Monday night. Precipitation will change to showers or flurries on Tuesday. Colder air and northerly winds will follow Tuesday night into Wednesday, changing precipitation back to periods of snow, with some accumulation possible. Strong easterly winds are likely along the West Coast Monday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of snow, blowing snow, and strong winds is expected from Monday night through to Wednesday morning. Snow will develop Monday evening and may become heavy at times overnight Monday into Tuesday. Total snowfall accumulations could well exceed 30 cm in some areas by Wednesday morning, particularly over higher elevations on the east facing side of the Great Northern Peninsula. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to between 70 and 90 km/h will accompany the snow and cause poor visibilities in blowing snow, especially on Tuesday and Tuesday night in areas where the precipitation remains as snow. South and east of White Bay, snowfall amounts will be much lower, as the precipitation begins as rain late Monday before changing to snow and then back through an extended period of ice pellets and freezing rain to rain on Tuesday. The precipitation is expected to taper off by Wednesday morning but strong northerly winds will continue throughout the day on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-15T19:41:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T01:22:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4148695867.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A low pressure system approaching the province from the southwest is forecast to cross New Brunswick Monday night before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Precipitation is expected to begin as a mix of snow and ice pellets tonight for northernmost regions. Elsewhere, precipitation should begin as freezing rain then transition through to rain by Monday morning. The rain is likely to persist into Monday evening before changing to flurries Monday night as the low pulls away. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are forecast. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T16:59:21-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant late season snowfall overnight. Snow across central portions of Ontario has tapered off somewhat this evening. However, it should reintensify overnight. The snow will come to an end Monday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are likely by Monday morning. There will also be a risk of freezing rain in some areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts between 15 and 25 centimetres is expected over these areas on Monday. Snow will be heavy at times and could therefore accumulate quickly. This accumulation of snow could result in broken tree limbs. The snow will become mixed with ice pellets and will change to rain during the day over some areas of the Gaspe Peninsula. Over the Northern Gaspe Peninsula and the Lower North Shore, the snow will persist into Tuesday. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continuing tonight over higher elevation areas. Several hours of freezing rain are likely over areas of higher elevation before changing back to snow overnight into Monday morning. For lower elevation areas, temperatures will likely remain just above the freezing mark with 10 to 25 mm of rain possible before changing to snow overnight or Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

Precipitation should change to snow overnight or early Monday morning with a few centimetres possible. There is also a risk of brief freezing rain. Motorists are advised to prepare for potentially hazardous travel conditions tonight. Precipitation will come to and end Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Strong easterly winds gusting to 80 km/h are forecast to develop in the Wreckhouse area Monday afternoon. Wind gusts will rapidly increase to near 130 km/h Monday evening. The winds are expected to diminish below warning criteria early Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A major spring storm will hit Eastern Quebec Monday through Tuesday. Precipitation will begin as snow tonight and change to rain at midday Monday. Heavy downpours may cause flash floods and flooding in low lying areas. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T18:19:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T02:20:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1857798650.2019
Area: New-Richmond - Bonaventure area, Restigouche - Carleton area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall continuing tonight. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm are possible. The ground is still at least partially frozen over portions of Southern Ontario. As a result, the ground will have a limited ability to absorb this rainfall. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. The rain will taper off from west to east overnight. Some snow is also possible overnight and early Monday morning, but any accumulation should be light. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T11:35:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-15T03:36:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0288767007.2019
Area: Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Kaladar - Bannockburn - Bon Echo Park, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes, Apsley - Woodview - Northern Peterborough County, Lindsay - Southern Kawartha Lakes, Peterborough City - Lakefield - Southern Peterborough County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A major storm will hit the Lower North Shore Monday night into Tuesday. 30 to 50 centimetres of heavy snow, strong winds, and blowing snow are expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T18:17:16-00:00

Area: Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon, Anticosti
